sect1.title: 130 Mycotoxins*
sect1.para: DIANIRIS LUCIANO-ROSARIO AND NANCY P. KELLER

Mycotoxins are secondary metabolites produced by many different species of ubiquitous fungi that have adverse effects on humans and animals. Secondary metabolites, also referred to as natural products, are not required for growth in laboratory conditions, but afford protective roles for the producing fungi. These roles range from protection from predators to exclusion of other microbes for niche securement (1, 2). Accordingly, many secondary metabolites are bioactive and cause damage when ingested by humans and animals. Not all toxic compounds produced by fungi are referred to as mycotoxins; for example, yeast and mushroom poisons are excluded by convention, compounds mainly inhibitory to bacteria are termed antibiotics, and those toxic to plants are called phytotoxins, although there can be overlap in toxicity to several kingdoms (3). Currently, more than 500 different mycotoxins have been discovered (4), and this number is increasing continuously with the application of modern mass spectrometry-based profiling and metabolomics workflows (5, 6). In this chapter we review the most common mycotoxins and their relevance to sick building syndrome (SBS), bioterrorism, and food safety. We briefly address the impact of mycotoxins on animal and human health but do not focus on the impacts of mycotoxins on health costs or the economy, as these topics have been reviewed extensively elsewhere (7–12). The reader is also referred to other recent reviews on mycotoxins (3, 11, 13, 14).

sect2.title: CHEMICAL CLASSIFICATION AND BIOSYNTHESIS OF MYCOTOXINS
sect2.para: The vast majority of mycotoxins, and indeed all fungal secondary metabolites, arise from a few well-known chemical precursors. Polyketides, like fatty acids, are synthesized from acyl CoA, nonribosomal peptides from amino acids, alkaloids from prenylated aromatic amino acids utilizing a dimethylallyltryptophan synthase, and terpenes from isoprene.Figure 1 provides a listing of some of the most commonly encountered mycotoxins, with their chemical class and structure, and Table 1 presents the producing fungi. Among the biosynthetic categories cited above, the polyketide chemical class derived from acetate metabolism appears to dominate (15). It is important to mention that among the nine classes of mycotoxins shown in Fig. 1, only trichothecenes (terpene) and ergot alkaloids (nonribosomal peptide and prenylated tryptophan) do not belong to the polyketide family. However, some of the more uncommon mycotoxins are derived solely from terpene or nonribosomal peptide/alkaloid origins.

The structure, and in some cases biochemistry, of the most common mycotoxins was elucidated earlier than the genetics. However, within the past decade, the genes encoding the enzymes required to synthesize many common mycotoxins have been found (13). The first mycotoxin gene clusters to be characterized were the aflatoxin cluster in both Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus (16, 17) and the sterigmatocystin cluster in Aspergillus nidulans (18). The finding that the genes were clustered in a single genetic locus has turned out to be a hallmark of fungal secondary metabolites (15). The physical clustering of metabolic genes has a significant impact on their regulation (19, 20). Therein, it is important to mention that gene clusters coding for the biosynthesis of mycotoxins often, but not necessarily, include a gene encoding a transcription factor that specifically modulates the expression of the rest of the genes within the cluster. The molecular genetics of fungal secondary metabolite clusters has been the subject of many recent reviews (19, 21–23). Figure 2 summarizes our current understanding of the gene clusters for the mycotoxins described in this chapter.

sect1.title: Aflatoxins
sect1.para: The aflatoxin class of mycotoxins was the first to be discovered and studied. Some of the most common aflatoxins (Fig. 1) are aflatoxins B1, B2, G1, and G2, named for their blue or green fluorescence under UV light (24), with aflatoxin B1 being the most potent natural carcinogen known and a known cause of liver cancer (25). More recently, this toxin has been associated with gallbladder cancer in Chile, and other adverse effects to a variety of organs such as the brain, heart, ovaries, and kidneys have been documented (26). The aflatoxin gene cluster (Fig. 2) is over 70 kb in length, reflective of the many biosynthetic genes required to build this metabolite. There have been several recent reviews of aflatoxins and the producing fungi (27, 28).

This high-profile mycotoxin is produced by several species ofAspergillus, in particular A. flavus and A. parasiticus. A. flavus is the most common contaminant of agricultural products including cereals, rice, figs, nuts, and tobacco (29, 30). Contamination of crops can occur in the fields before harvest, especially in times of drought (30, 31), or during storage, depending upon the moisture content of the substrate and the humidity of the storage conditions (29, 32). Aflatoxin is mainly problematic in countries with tropical and subtropical climates where temperature and humidity conditions are optimal to fungus growth and toxin production (33). However, its danger has spread beyond its predicted geographical boundaries and has reached countries previously considered as relatively safe from this toxin, due to effects of climate change such as increasing temperatures and CO2 levels and altered rainfall patterns (34, 35). Aflatoxin contamination can be the cause of a variety of economic and health problems and is particularly problematic in developing countries (36). For instance, the presence of aflatoxin in grain significantly lowers the grain’s value, as feed or an export commodity, because of the toxin’s link to increased mortality in farm animals (37). Further, ingestion of aflatoxin by dairy cows can lead to the presence of aflatoxin M1, a hydroxylated form of B1, in their milk, leading to potential human health risks, as aflatoxin M1 levels do not decrease upon milk processing (38).

There are substantial differences in the susceptibilities of vertebrate species to aflatoxin exposure. One of the first indications of the effects of aflatoxins was observed in 1960, when more than 100,000 turkey poults died from aflatoxin-contaminated feed, an outbreak named “turkey X disease” (39). Other outbreaks have occurred in ducklings and chickens (40), swine (41), and calves (42), due mostly to contaminated Brazilian peanut meal used as feed. The most recent notable outbreak of acute aflatoxicosis in humans was in Kenya in 2004 (43), followed by fewer yet significant outbreaks in 2005 and 2006 (44) and an outbreak in Tanzania in 2016 (45). The clinical profile of aflatoxin ingestion in humans in acute toxicity is predominantly associated with hepatoxicity and can include a variety of signs and symptoms like yellowing of the skin, bleeding, nausea, itching, convulsions, lethargy, coma, and death, among others (46). Chronic toxicity is more likely associated with hepatocellular carcinoma and impaired growth and development in children (46). These outbreaks illustrate the need for monitoring and regulation of the amount of mycotoxins in foods meant for human consumption, a luxury not normally available to developing countries. Aflatoxin contamination of pet food, particularly dog food, is a recurring problem in the United States and other countries, as ingestion with contaminated products often results in death (47, 48).

sect1.title: Citrinin
sect1.para: Citrinin (Fig. 1) is a simple, low-molecular-weight compound that crystallizes as light yellow needles. It was tested as an antibiotic and a treatment for ulcers (49) before the discovery of its mycotoxic effects. The most common organisms producing citrinin are Penicillium citrinum; P. expansum; P. aurantiogriseum; P. camemberti used to produce cheese; Aspergillus neoniveus; Aspergillus oryzae used to produce sake and soy sauce; Aspergillus terreus; and Monascus spp. used to produce red food dyes (3). Focused work with Monascus aurantiacus and Monascus ruber (50) provides the best analysis of the citrinin cluster (Fig. 2).

Citrinin, first isolated fromP. citrinum, has been associated with Japanese yellow rice disease (51). It has also been found in various grains, peanuts, and fruits, and there is limited evidence of its surviving unchanged in cereal products (3). Citrinin-producing fungi are major producers of other classes of mycotoxins including ochratoxin, aflatoxin, and patulin. Thus, co-occurrence of citrinin with these fungal metabolites was reported in rice (52) and apples (53). Citrinin has demonstrated nephrotoxic effects on all animal species tested (54) and was shown to inhibit dehydrogenase activity in rat kidneys, liver, and brain (55). Recently, citrinin was attributed to complication of a fowl adenovirus outbreak, as it was detected in poultry kidneys (56). However, as there have been no proven reported outbreaks of human citrinin poisoning, its relevance to human health remains unknown, although new techniques are in development to assess citrinin exposure (57). Citrinin poisoning has been implicated for livestock deaths (58). Symptoms in model laboratory animals fed citrinin include dehydration, anemia, body weight loss, kidney failure, and decreased fecundity. Clinical symptoms are not reported for citrinin exposure in humans, although this is not to say there have not been exposure incidences (59).

sect1.title: Cyclopiazonic acid (CPA)
sect1.para: Cyclopiazonic acid (Fig. 1) is an indole-tetramic acid mycotoxin produced by several species of Penicillium and Aspergillus (60, 61). It has demonstrated severe toxicity on all species tested, including rats (62), chickens (63), dogs (64), and pigs (65). Contamination of various food products, including grains, meats, and cheese, with CPA is sometimes coincident with aflatoxin contamination (66). As such, it is suspected that some of the symptoms of “turkey X disease” may have been due to the toxicity of cocontaminant CPA (67).

Interestingly, the CPA gene cluster is present inA. flavus (Fig. 2), but truncated in its domesticated form, A. oryzae (68); this is reminiscent of repeated findings of truncated or mutated aflatoxin clusters in this species (69). A. oryzae, used in the manufacture of fermented rice products, does not produce CPA due to a deletion in the backbone gene of the cluster; in some strains where the backbone gene is present, CPA is converted to a less toxic compound, 2-oxoCPA, by an enzyme not present in A. flavus (70). Little is known about its toxicity to humans, but it may affect the heart (71) and liver, and is thought to cause “kodo poisoning,” a clinical manifestation that occurs when animals or humans ingest contaminated kodo millet, a cereal domesticated in India. General symptoms in humans can be classified as gastrointestinal (vomiting and nausea) and neurological (delirium, depression, and unconsciousness) (72, 73). Readers are referred to a recent review on CPA impact on world health (74).

sect1.title: Ergot Alkaloids
sect1.para: Ergot alkaloids, produced by the ergot fungusClaviceps purpurea, are the causative agent of ergotism, or St. Anthony’s fire, which can manifest either as a gangrenous or convulsive condition following ingestion of contaminated grains, especially rye (75). St. Anthony’s fire acquired its name due to the hallucinogenic symptoms exhibited upon ingestion. These symptoms were first described by the Christian monk Anthony during the 3rd century CE and portrayed as divine visions. It is not clear and only hypothesized that these visions were caused by consumption of ergots (76). Two main classes of ergot alkaloids exist: lysergic acid derivatives and clavines. Both are indole alkaloids derived from tetracyclic ergoline. Lysergic acid, common to all ergot alkaloids, often forms amide, amino acid, or peptide derivatives, e.g., ergine, ergonovine, lysergic acid diethylamide, and ergovaline. The clavines contain the ergoline structure but do not have amino acid or peptide components, e.g., pergolide and lisuride (77). Semisynthetic ergot alkaloids have been developed through decades of research, which began with the series of lysergic acid derivatives that included the infamous hallucinogen LSD (78). Most recently, ergot alkaloids have been investigated for their anticancer potential (79) and their effect on serotonin and serotonin receptors (80, 81). A representative compound, ergotamine, is shown in Fig. 1, and the gene cluster characterized in C. pupurea is shown in Fig. 2.

Aspergillus, Balansia, Claviceps, Epichloë, and Neotyphodium spp. have been found to produce ergot alkaloids. Aspergillus fumigatus has been shown to produce fumigaclavines A, B, and C and festuclavine, first described for C. purpurea and later for Neotyphodium (82). Modern methods of cleaning grains have all but eliminated the threat to the human food chain. However, ergotism remains an important veterinary concern, as symptoms of gangrene, convulsions, and abortion in cattle, sheep, pigs, and chickens mimic those in humans (82).

sect1.title: Fumonisins
sect1.para: Fumonisins (Fig. 1) are among the most recently discovered mycotoxins. In the late 1970s and early 1980s it was determined that fumonisins produced by Gibberella fujikuroi were the cause of leukoencephalomalacia in horses (83) and hepatocarcinoma in rats (84). By 2002, there were 28 known fumonisin analogs, separated into groups A, B, C, and P (85). Fusarium proliferatum, Gibberella nygamai, Aspergillus niger, and Alternaria alternata also produce these mycotoxins (86, 87). The fumonisin cluster is characterized in several species including Gibberella moniliformis (Fig. 2).

Besides the syndromes mentioned above, fumonisins have been shown to cause pulmonary edema and hydrothorax in swine (88) and is of particular concern in horses, a mammal very sensitive to fumonisin (89). G. fujikuroi, the major producer of fumonisins, can have an important effect on the supply of corn, as it causes a variety of blights and rots depending on environmental conditions (90). There is considerable concern and evidence that fumonisins cause several human diseases, particularly esophageal cancer (91), and some evidence to support poisoning outbreaks in India (92). Likely due to these concerns, international monitoring systems are now in place for this metabolite (93), which, unfortunately, is often found in food and feed products, cocontaminated with aflatoxin (94). The recent review of Kamle et al. (95) represents a must-read to anyone interested in fumonisin toxicity.

sect1.title: Ochratoxins
sect1.para: Ochratoxins A and B (Fig. 1) are produced by several Penicillium spp. including P. verrucosum and P. nordicum; the latter is used as the model for the ochratoxin cluster (Fig. 2). Several Aspergillus spp. especially A. ochraceus, also produce ochratoxins. These toxins can be carcinogenic, immunosuppressive, and nephrotoxic (37, 96). Ochratoxin A, first discovered to be toxic to animals in 1965 (97), is more common than ochratoxin B and can be metabolized by cytochrome P450 in the liver (98). Ochratoxins are most often found contaminating barley, but may be present in oats, rye, wheat, wine grapes (99), and coffee beans (3, 97). They are of particular concern because they can be carried through the food chain, especially in milk and pork (100). Scandinavian countries, particularly Denmark, have had high incidence of porcine nephropathy and high levels of ochratoxin A contamination (101). Some studies speculate that ochratoxin A may contribute to Parkinson’s disease (102).

sect1.title: Patulin
sect1.para: Patulin (Fig. 1) was first isolated in the 1940s from Penicillium griseofulvum, and efforts were made to mass-produce it for its antibiotic effects (103). However, patulin was reclassified as a mycotoxin in the 1960s following discovery of its toxicity to plants and animals (3). Effects of acute poisoning such as hematemesis, diarrhea, lethargy, tachypnea, massive atelectasis, and alveolar hemorrhages, were described in different animal species (104–106). To date, there are no documented cases of acute or chronic toxicity reported in humans. The chronic exposure to patulin was likewise associated with diverse toxic effects, mainly cytotoxicity and genotoxicity in mice, Chinese hamster cell lines, and human epithelial cell lines (107–109). Patulin occurs commonly in unfermented juice made from Penicilium expansum-contaminated apples and pears (110), whereas ascladiol, its direct biosynthetic precursor, has been reported in alcoholic beverages, mainly apple cider (111). The 15-gene patulin gene cluster and many of its global regulators have been characterized in P. expansum (Fig. 2) (112).

Though toxic at high concentrationsin vitro, natural patulin poisoning in humans has yet to be shown (3). Nevertheless, due to concern over its prevalence in apple juice and other items preferentially consumed by children, several countries limit patulin levels in certain foods and beverages (113). The reader is referred to a review on the biosynthesis and toxicity of patulin (114).

sect1.title: Trichothecenes
sect1.para: Trichothecene mycotoxins are secondary metabolites of a variety ofFusarium, Myrothecium, Phomopsis, Stachybotrys, Trichoderma, and Trichothecium spp., among others. Some of the most common and well-studied Fusarium trichothecenes (Fig. 1) are T-2 toxin, HT-2 toxin, diacetoxyscirpenol, nivalenol, and deoxynivalenol, also called DON or vomitoxin. Several fungal species have had their trichothecene gene clusters characterized (Fig. 2).

DON is one of the most common mycotoxins found in grain, including barley, oats, rye, and wheat. When ingested in large quantities by livestock, it can cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Ingestion of smaller quantities results in weight loss and feed refusal (115). DON can also suppress bovine and porcine neutrophil function in vitro (116). DON ingestion by humans occurs mainly by eating contaminated plant products like corn, wheat, oats, barley, rice, and other grains. Although there is a possibility of secondary exposure through the ingestion of foods of animal origins, it is unlikely (117). In humans, acute DON ingestion causes gastrointestinal upset including nausea, vomiting, dizziness, diarrhea, and headache, while chronic exposure is associated with augmented incidence of esophageal cancer (117). Stachybotrys chartarum produces several trichothecenes, including verrucarins B and J, roridin E, satratoxins F, G, and H, and isosatratoxins F, G, and H (118, 119). Stachybotrys-contaminated straw was first described as causing a highly fatal equine disease (120) and has since become better known as a factor in SBS, discussed below. Some studies report toxic outbreaks in populations consuming contaminated wheat products (121). The exhaustive review of Pinton and Oswald in 2014 (122) summarizes the available data concerning the toxicity of DON and other trichothecenes.

sect1.title: Zearalenone
sect1.para: Zearalenone (Fig. 1) is a nonsteroidal estrogen or phytoestrogen produced by various species of Gibberella, including G. pulicaris and G. tricincta (123). Gibberella is the genus name of the sexual stage of several Fusarium spp., and hence many refer to zearalenone as a Fusarium toxin; the zearalenone cluster was defined most thoroughly in Fusarium sporotrichioides (Fig. 2). Zearalenone is a common contaminant of cereal crops worldwide and has been implicated in hyperestrogenism of farm animals as a result of digestion of moldy corn and grains (124, 125). Some of the symptoms of hyperestrogenism are enlargement of the uterus and nipples, vaginal prolapse, and infertility (126). Recently zearalenone was proved to be immunotoxic, causing thymic atrophy with histological and thymocyte phenotype changes besides a decrease in the B-cell percentage in the spleen (126). Several outbreaks of zearalenone poisoning of swine have been reported (127). A recent comprehensive review outlines zearalenone effects on human health and metabolism and neutralization methods (128).

sect2.title: FOOD SAFETY
sect2.para: Consumption of moldy food products is the leading cause of mycotoxicoses in agricultural animals and humans alike. Contamination can occur at any point, ranging from the crop field through storage and shipping. The economic consequences of mycotoxin contamination are immense, and mycotoxins pose a higher chronic dietary risk than synthetic contaminants, plant toxins, food additives, or pesticide residues (129). Tables 1 and 2 list the mycotoxins discussed in this chapter and their common substrates. The reader should note that neither table is exhaustive, and other fungi and substrates can be involved in mycotoxin poisonings.

sect1.title: Regulation
sect1.para: Considering the difficulty of preventing mycotoxin contamination and the harmful effects of these deleterious molecules on human and animal health, many countries have enacted regulations for levels of mycotoxins in food and animal feed. Regulations for mycotoxins were first established in the late 1960s in the United States. Subsequently, new limits and regulations were set by the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA), which is enforced by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The latter has established specific “action” levels for aflatoxin and “advisory” levels for other classes of mycotoxins (130). European countries were also among the first to set EU-harmonized regulations and limits for mycotoxins in food and feed (131). The regulatory guidelines for limiting mycotoxins differ between countries, but have been summarized in compendia published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and more recently reviewed (113, 132). Table 3 summarizes the main mycotoxins with their major toxic effects and toxicological reference values.

sect1.title: Detection
sect1.para: Based on the wide-ranging structural diversity of mycotoxins, the serious health risks caused by these compounds, and their high chemical stability, it has been very crucial to develop vigorous and effective detection techniques. Mycotoxins are often present in smaller amounts than other interfering substances, requiring that each be separated from its substrate and studied by a unique assay. Generally, sample preparation consists of an extraction step and a purification step. Though this method is the most definitive, it is very expensive and time-consuming. Thus, newer screening methods for the presence of mycotoxins have been developed over the past decade. On the other hand, many of these screening methods are still plagued by cross-reactivity and require confirmation with more selective validated methods.

Several reviews exist on current detection methodologies (133, 134). Confirmatory tests and novel screening techniques include immunoassays such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), fluorescence polarization immunoassay, surface-plasmon resonance, and other conductometric measurements (135). High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and gas chromatography (GC) are widely used, and, since the introduction of atmospheric pressure ionization, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry has become a routine technique for detecting the presence of mycotoxins, including tricothecenes, ochratoxins, zearalenone, fumonisins, and aflatoxins (136). The latest official methods, validated by the Association of Official Analytical Chemists International, are based on immunoaffinity column cleanup of conventional extracts, followed by fluorescently labeled HPLC (37). Over the past few years, novel approaches such as sensors and biosensors for mycotoxin detection have emerged as promising alternatives to classical analysis methods due to their high sensitivity and selectivity, usability, and low cost (137). Even though the performance and applicability of such techniques need some improvements, they were already proven to be potent tools for analysis of aflatoxins (138), ochratoxins (139), and zearalenone (140). The reader is referred to comprehensive reviews of recent developments in analytical protocols (141–143).

sect1.title: Effects of Climate Change
sect1.para: It is estimated that one-quarter to almost three-quarters of the world’s crops are contaminated to some extent with mycotoxins, depending on the country sampled (144, 145); this proportion varies from year to year based on environmental factors. There is much evidence of the influence of environmental factors, mainly temperature, humidity, drought, insect attack, and other plant stressors, on mycotoxin production by molds. Further, the pathogenicity of different molds may be additive, and competition between mold species may be temperature dependent (146). Each species and its ability to produce mycotoxins must be evaluated independently in its optimum growth conditions. For wheat species, infection of the cereal ears by Gibberella spp., particularly G. zeae, a predominant producer of DON, is enhanced by warm, humid weather (147). At the other extreme, production of fumonisins and aflatoxins is greater under drought conditions. Warmer temperatures and fewer frost days result in more insect and plant pathogens surviving the winter and causing plants to be more susceptible to mold infestation. Recent studies have shown an increase in mycotoxin contamination of multiple crops (148). In summary, climate changes in any particular region may result in radical changes in the amount and type of crop damage and mycotoxin contamination.

sect1.title: Current Practices and the Future of Prevention and Amelioration of Mycotoxin Contamination
sect1.para: Several different approaches are currently being developed to protect the food supply from mycotoxin contamination, including measures taken before, during, and after cultivation of crops, yet the most reliable preventive treatments are still cultural practices and humidity control in post-harvest facilities. Though most breeding successes have been reported for wheat and barley, it is also essential to breed for resistance in other crops, such as corn and oats (149). Several laboratories have attempted to create transgenic lines resistant to various mycotoxigenic fungi, but none are in production. However, several reports suggest that Bt crops, those transgenically expressing insecticidal Bacillus thuringiensis toxins, are less susceptible to mycotoxin contamination due to decreased insect infestation (150). Indeed, insecticides have been shown to reduce the growth of Aspergillus and resultant accumulation of ochratoxin A (151).

One biological control discussed but not implemented to any degree is the application of mycoviruses, which are typically easily spread through asexual fungal spores. Though many mycoviruses have minimal effects on their host fungi, they have the potential to be used as vectors for resistance genes. This approach may expand with the increasing availability of virus-specific molecular detection methods (8). Additionally, a recent study shows that the application of nontoxigenic strains of A. flavus to corn plant whorls prior to tasseling significantly reduced aflatoxin accumulation, presumably through competition with toxigenic strains (152). This latter method appears promising and is being assessed in many different climates worldwide (146).

Natural extracts have proven to be a safe alternative to toxic chemical insecticides, and for biological blocking agents whose efficiency is yet to be established (153). Several natural extracts, such as essential oils and organic and aqueous extracts from herbs and spices, have been described as having fungicidal and antimycotoxigenic activities (154–156). Their application in the food industry is being evoked through diverse methods such as edible films (157), active packaging (158), or by vapor contact (159).

Finally, recent studies have concentrated on degradation of mycotoxins following crop harvest. Many microorganisms, such as soil and water bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and specific enzymes isolated from microbial systems, degrade mycotoxins, specifically aflatoxins (160). The addition of sodium carbonate and other feed additives has demonstrated success, lowering mortality and reducing adverse effects of mycotoxin-contaminated feed in livestock (85, 161).

sect2.title: BIOTERRORISM
sect2.para: In response to concern about possible use of mycotoxins in bioterrorism, the Committee on Protection from Mycotoxins was formed by the National Research Council in 1982 (162). Following years of research, Ciegler proposed the use of mycotoxins as chemical weapons in 1986 (163). However, the choice of aflatoxin as a weapon of mass destruction is odd at best; the effects of aflatoxicosis, such as liver cancer, are too slow-acting to be effective during war.

Trichothecenes are much more suited for warfare than aflatoxins; they act immediately upon contact, and several milligrams can be lethal. Of historical note is the “yellow rain” incident of 1981 (164). The United States accused the Soviet Union of using nivalenol, DON, and T-2 toxin against Hmong tribesmen in Cambodia and Laos. However, it was later concluded that this “yellow rain” was not a weapon but the excreta of swarms of wild Asian honeybees (165).

The use of mycotoxins in bioterrorism has been assessed by several investigators in recent years (3, 166, 167). Aflatoxins and trichothecenes have been tested for combined toxicity and were found to have additive effects in most cases. The combination of these mycotoxins resulted in a synergistic effect in human bronchial epithelial cells (168). Interestingly, chlorine dioxide may be effective in the detoxification of trichothecenes, roridin A, and verrucarin A (169) in the case of widespread exposure. T-2 toxin, along with aflatoxin, received some notoriety as possible biological weapons used in the Gulf War (170). However, there are no clear data to support a role for either mycotoxin in ensuing illnesses from veterans of this war (171). Much of the data addressing mycotoxins in biological warfare remain classified and thus unresolved. In general, it is accepted that, while the presence of mycotoxin weapons may cause terror, the actual use of such weapons would not be effective or reliable in a time of war.

sect2.title: SICK BUILDING SYNDROME
sect2.para: SBS is a loosely defined term that applies to indoor environments suspected of causing a variety of health problems for occupants. The buildings usually have many issues, including water damage; improper heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems; poor construction; and bacterial, fungal, and/or insect infestation. Symptoms may include eye, nose, and throat irritation; fatigue; headache; lack of concentration; frequent respiratory tract infections; shortness of breath, dizziness, and nausea (172). Mycotoxins are just one of many factors considered as possible contributors to SBS. Several mycotoxin-producing fungi have been implicated, including Alternaria, Aspergillus, Cladosporium, Chaetomium, and Penicillium spp. One of the most widely investigated species is Stachybotrys chartarum. For comprehensive reviews, see references 7 and 173.

For some decades, many reviews of SBS concluded that there is no evidence that molds inside buildings present a threat to life for healthy members of the general population in typical exposures (7, 172). A further argument against mycotoxins as the cause of SBS symptoms is that most mycotoxins are not volatile, and therefore widespread exposure is unlikely. Moreover, the conditions conducive for mold growth are not necessarily optimal for mycotoxin production, and fungi differ in their abilities to produce mycotoxins.

However, during the past years, more studies have been conducted to evaluate the association between SBS symptoms and relevant toxins from indoor airborne fungi. The new findings contradict earlier reports and suggest a significant contribution of airborne mycotoxins to signs of illness and discomfort in healthy people (174, 175). Thus, the contribution of mycotoxins to SBS still remains an open question.

sect2.title: CONCLUSIONS
sect2.para: There are several classes of mycotoxins, produced by a wide range of fungal species, which have been linked to various environmental issues such as cancer, SBS, veterinary problems, bioterrorism, and food safety. Over the past decade, there have been many developments in the processes for identifying mycotoxin contamination as well as advances in methods to control its production. Much research and education are yet needed to reduce the threat of mycotoxin-producing fungal species to the health of human, livestock, and plant populations and its resultant effects on the international economy.

figure.title: Figure 2 The genetic structure of the biosynthetic gene clusters for each of the major groups of mycotoxins in the particular species. The backbone genes are represented in blue and the specific transcription factors in gray. Each gene is represented as an arrow in the direction of transcription with the name of the gene above it. In the aflatoxin pathway gene cluster, the old gene names are labeled above the line and the new gene names are labeled below the line. Diagonal bisection of a cluster signifies that it is not contiguous. The 5-kb scale bar applies to all of the clusters except the ergot alkaloids cluster, to which the 2.5-kb scale bar applies.
